title: Bahubali Director Rajamouli Aces IIT Test
text:
Email 16 
Probing questions from young minds didn’t rattle Baahubali director SS Rajamouli, who floored the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) students with his smart replies on Saturday, during a lecture. 
Taking time off his hectic schedule to participate in an event organised on the premises of the institute, Rajamouli, who flew in from Hyderabad, took questions ranging from whether he would like to direct Rajinikanth to what qualities he would look for in a filmmaker. 
Replying to question whether he would like to direct a film with Rajinikanth, the hit filmmaker said, “If you ask that question to any director in the South, they will have only one reply,” he said much to the delight of the audience who cheered for his response. 
He continued, “If I make a film with Rajini sir, I would expect people to not to listen to any dialogue for the first 10 days because the theatres would be echoing with loud cheers.” 
On what one must do to be a filmmaker like Rajamouli, the director said, “Why do you want to be a Rajamouli? Have you ever heard of any other director who has made it big by wanting to be like another director?” When a student retorted that Rajamouli had, in his earlier interviews, mentioned the name of a certain director, Rajamouli said, “I admire him and his work but I did not want to be like him.” 
Most students were interested in knowing how many parts he would take if he were to direct the Mahabharata. Rajamouli said he would require a minimum of four parts over of six years.Would he then direct the film? Rajamouli replied, “When I decided to make Baahubali, Prabhas and I believed in it. He trusted me so much that he was willing to give me three years. Now, if for Baahubali, I need an actor to give me three years, imagine making a film on the scale of Mahabharata. Practically speaking, how many actors will be able to give six years of their time to a director?” Asking the students to be true to themselves, the director said, “If you want to be a director, first you must enjoy telling stories. That is the first test.”
